title: How to Make a Wonka Bar

steps.headline: Melt your milk baking chocolate bar in a bowl in a microwave for 2-3 minutes.
steps.description: You could also melt the chocolate by other methods, but if microwaving just make sure that every 30 seconds you take it out and stir well, you don't want any lumps in the chocolate.

steps.headline: Pour the melted chocolate into a Wonka mold.
steps.description: You could add caramel or nuts for flavoring, just spread them out so they aren't too close, the last thing that you want is a lot of caramel on one side and hardly any on the other.

steps.headline: Chill the bar in a refrigerator until solid.
steps.description: You can test it by taking the bar out and dipping something GENTLY against it, if the chocolate is still liquid, let it solidify for longer.

steps.headline: Wrap the newly solidified bar in aluminum foil after removing it from the mold.
steps.description: Again, the key word is to remove the bar from the mold GENTLY.

steps.headline: Go onto Microsoft Word or Paint and copy and paste a Wonka wrapper.
steps.description: "Text wrap" the wrapper (pun not intended) so that it fits your bar, you may need to try different sizes.

steps.headline: Print it off on poster paper.
steps.description: You could also print it on normal A4 Paper if you're testing the wrapper size.

steps.headline: Place and physically wrap your wrapper around the bar.
steps.description: Line up everything so that it looks authentic, look up photos of the wrapper you're using and try to match them.

steps.headline: Enjoy your Wonka bar!
steps.description: Well done. You now have a homemade Wonka bar!

text: Melt your milk baking chocolate bar in a bowl in a microwave for 2-3 minutes. You could also melt the chocolate by other methods, but if microwaving just make sure that every 30 seconds you take it out and stir well, you don't want any lumps in the chocolate. Pour the melted chocolate into a Wonka mold. You could add caramel or nuts for flavoring, just spread them out so they aren't too close, the last thing that you want is a lot of caramel on one side and hardly any on the other. Chill the bar in a refrigerator until solid. You can test it by taking the bar out and dipping something GENTLY against it, if the chocolate is still liquid, let it solidify for longer. Wrap the newly solidified bar in aluminum foil after removing it from the mold. Again, the key word is to remove the bar from the mold GENTLY. Go onto Microsoft Word or Paint and copy and paste a Wonka wrapper. "Text wrap" the wrapper (pun not intended) so that it fits your bar, you may need to try different sizes. Print it off on poster paper. You could also print it on normal A4 Paper if you're testing the wrapper size. Place and physically wrap your wrapper around the bar. Line up everything so that it looks authentic, look up photos of the wrapper you're using and try to match them. Enjoy your Wonka bar! Well done. You now have a homemade Wonka bar!
